paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted genetic variant information for the TTR gene, including penetrance data.

patients.demographics: Various populations including Portuguese, Swedish, Japanese, Brazilian, and Majorcan

individual_records.evidence_sentence: In the former, disease onset often occurs before the age of 40 years, with a progressive sensory-motor and autonomic neuropathy.
Carriers of the gene may live to an advanced age without symptoms of the disease.

functional_data.summary: The Val30Met mutation is known to destabilize the TTR protein, leading to amyloid fibril formation.

variants.segregation_data: Segregates with disease in families, particularly in endemic regions.
variants.population_frequency: 4% in endemic areas of northern Sweden; 80% penetrance by age 50 in Portugal.
variants.additional_notes: The Val30Met mutation is the most common TTR mutation associated with TTR-FAP.
key_quotes: Val30Met is the most prevalent TTR-FAP mutation in the world.
In Portugal, the penetrance is high (80% by 50 years).

individual_records.phenotype_details: Cardiac amyloidosis with heart failure symptoms
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Most individuals developing late-onset cardiac amyloidosis.

functional_data.summary: The Val122Ile mutation is associated with amyloid deposition in cardiac tissues.

variants.segregation_data: Segregates with disease in families, particularly in African American populations.
variants.source_location: Prevalence and age at onset section, paragraph 3
variants.additional_notes: The Val122Ile mutation is primarily associated with cardiac symptoms.
key_quotes: The frequency of Val122Ile mutation in the African American population is 3% to 3.9%.
Most individuals developing late-onset cardiac amyloidosis.

tables_processed.table_caption: Summary of TTR mutations and their associated phenotypes.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data was extracted from the main text and tables.
